div.p: A RESOLUTION Of three Important Que≈øtions (premis'd as a Foundation to an intended Expo≈øition of the fourth and fifth Chapters of the Apocalyp≈øe) in An≈øwer to the late Reverend and Learned Dr. H. M.

Wherein is ≈øhewed,
I. That the Fourth and Fifth Chapters of the Revelation, are properly a Prophecy of things to come to pa≈øs after St. John's receiving of the Vi≈øion of them.
II. That by Opening of the Book, Rev. v. is meant, or prefigured the Explaining of it.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: AS to this little Treati≈øe (the ≈ømallne≈øs whereof would ea≈øily be excus'd, if it were not al≈øo of it ≈øelf imperfect, as de≈øign'd in order only to ≈øome other thing) I de≈øire the Reader to take this following account. It is now more than four Years ago, ≈øince I wrote an Expo≈øition on the fourth and fifth Chapters of the Revelation, and communicated it to ≈øome certain Friends, whom I thought be≈øt able to make a right Judgment of it; who, for the most part, mode≈øtly excu≈øing their unacquaintedne≈øs with the≈øe Studies, advis'd me to impart it to the famous Dr. H. M. To him therefore I di≈øpatch'd it; who, quite contrary to what I imagin'd, finding very little to ≈øay again≈øt the Particulars of my Expo≈øition, ≈øet him≈øelf wholly to overthrow the very Foundation on which I built; and which I thought ≈øo plain, that no body could have oppos'd it. In ≈øhort, the main, and (in effect) the only things that he objected, were the contrary Propo≈øitions to what I here a≈ø≈øert in the≈øe Papers.

Whereupon, about the end of February 1685/6. I put forth the fir≈øt of the≈øe three Sheets; wherein I prove from the very Title pre≈øixt to tho≈øe very Chapters by the Spirit him≈øelf, that they are properly a Prophecy of things to come to pa≈øs after St. John's receiving the Vi≈øion; which Dr. M. with great earne≈øtne≈øs had denied in the xxi≈øt Chapter of his Paralipomena Prophetica (a Book which he put forth about November 1685, after he had ≈øeen my Expo≈øition) but he had never taken notice, that the SPIRIT him≈øelf has expre≈øly entitled it a Vi≈øion of future things, which was indeed
a very great Over≈øight in the Doctor. So I thought that my putting him in mind of this, would ea≈øily put an end to the Di≈øpute between us; there being nothing to be ≈øaid again≈øt ≈øo plain a Demon≈øtration. And indeed my Expectation did not fail me, for from that time to this, I have never had a word of An≈øwer from him; which, in effect, was yielding up the whole to me, that I contend for in the≈øe Papers. For if tho≈øe Chapters be A Prophecy of things to come to pa≈øs after St. John's receiving of the Vi≈øion, they were not either pa≈øt, or pre≈øent, at that time. And con≈øequently, the Opening of the ≈øealed Book, which St. John then ≈øaw, mu≈øt be a Type of the explaining of it afterwards (for it prefigures that mo≈øt naturally, and can prefigure nothing el≈øe) and al≈øo the Throne which he ≈øaw at the ≈øame time, mu≈øt needs be a Throne of God which was afterwards to be on Earth, and cannot ≈øignify his Throne in the highe≈øt Heaven, which exi≈øted before all Ages. Altho to make all as ≈øure as I could, I have prov'd the≈øe things by many other Arguments in the≈øe Papers. It is therefore highly to be pre≈øum'd that the Doctor would in all this time have defended his Book again≈øt that fir≈øt attempt of mine, if it had been po≈ø≈øible; but ≈øince he has not done it, we may well conclude, that as his Mode≈øty would not ≈øuffer him to confe≈øs his Error, otherwi≈øe than by Silence, ≈øo it would much le≈øs allow him to engage in defence of it. I lately hear, that ≈øince (viz. in Augu≈øt la≈øt) God has taken him to his Mercy; and let his Memory be ever precious. I hope it will be no Offence to tho≈øe that have a ju≈øt e≈øteem for it, if, before I publi≈øh my ≈øaid Expo≈øition to the World, I undertake to clear tho≈øe Points in difference between us, upon which I am to lay ≈øo great a ≈øtre≈øs; and which if I am not able to make good, it would be vain to meddle any further in this bu≈øine≈øs.

div.head: A VINDICATION of certain Papers (not yet made publick) concerning the Expo≈øition of the fourth and fifth Chapters of the Revelation, (the right under≈øtanding of which Chapters would be of the greate≈øt advantage to the Church:) from the Exceptions of the Reverend and Learned Dr. H. M.
div.p:
THere is no Vi≈øion in the whole Book of the Revelation that has been le≈øs under≈øtood hitherto, than that of the 4th and 5th Chapters; and yet there is none has been expounded with more ea≈øe to tho≈øe that have undertaken that Task, than tho≈øe Chapters have. For tho there be many Objections both very weighty, and very obvious, to be made again≈øt the Expo≈øitions of every one of them (for they all agree as to the main, in a literal kind of way of interpreting them (≈øuch as any Child that is but ju≈øt come to the u≈øe of Rea≈øon, would be apt at fir≈øt ≈øight to pitch upon) concurring unanimou≈øly in one grand mi≈øtake, That by the Lamb's coming and taking the Book out of the hand of him that ≈øat on the Throne, Rev. 7. is repre≈øented God's giving his Son the Revelation; tho there be many Objections, I ≈øay, both weighty and obvious, to be alledg'd again≈øt this way of expounding, yet no Man, tho never ≈øo learned, ingenious, or curious in the≈øe Speculations, has ≈øo much as mention'd one of them, till the learned and ingenious Dr. M. being urg'd by ≈øome Papers I ≈øent him a while ago, has been pleas'd both to in≈øert the Objections into his Paralipomena Prophetica, Chap. xxxiv. and to give us his Solutions of them. It is a glorious Vi≈øion, as any one may ≈øee by the bare letter of it; which made me, while I look'd upon it only by the Light which I receiv'd from others, never to read it over without a Sigh. For I could perceive nothing from their Expo≈øitions, but what is deliver'd much more plainly in other Scriptures: and I could not by any
means per≈øwade my ≈øelf that ≈øo magnificent a Vi≈øion as this is, was written only to inform us, how ob≈øcurely and my≈øteriou≈øly common Truths, well kown before, plain, ea≈øy, and familiar, might be repre≈øented.

I hope no Man will be ≈øo uncharitable as to interpret the de≈øign of what I have here ≈øaid, to be as if I meant to di≈øparage other Interpreters, to mo≈øt of whom for any commendable Quality I am no way comparable. For as I honour every Man that with ≈øo much as but a good intent has ≈øeem'd to have be≈øtowed his pains in explicating the≈øe My≈øteries: ≈øo I ingenuou≈øly profe≈øs that nothing but the love of Truth has mov'd me to lay open the ≈øeeming Incon≈øi≈øtencies of their Expo≈øition. In order to the manife≈øting of which Truth, when it ≈øhall be thought fit by tho≈øe that are the Judges of what is fit in ≈øuch ca≈øes; I ≈øhall now only endeavour to prepare the way, by ≈øhewing that which the Reverend and Learned Dr. M. is forced to deny at any rate, as being utterly incon≈øi≈øtent with his own and the common Hypothe≈øis, viz. That the Vi≈øion of the fourth and fifth Chapters of the Revelation is properly a Prophecy; and con≈øequently, that the de≈øign of the fifth Chapter is not to repre≈øent God's giving to his Son the Revelation.

That the fourth and fifth Chapters of the Revelation are a Prophecy. This appears ≈øo plainly from the Preface that the Spirit him≈øelf has prefixt to them, that one would think it impo≈ø≈øible for any Man to be mi≈øtaken in this Point. After this I looked (≈øays St. John, Chap. iv. 1.) and behold a Door was opened in Heaven; And the fir≈øt Voice which I heard was as it were of a Trumpet talking with me, ≈øaying, Come up hither, and I will ≈øhew thee things which mu≈øt be hereafter. Is not this as plain an Indication as can be de≈øired, that the things which St. John was now about to ≈øee, were things to come; and con≈øequently, that the ≈øeeing of tho≈øe things is prophe≈øying? But what were tho≈øe things which the Voice ≈øhewed him? What can they be, if not tho≈øe which immediately follow, of which St. John gives this Relation, ver. 2, 3, &c. And immediately, ≈øays he, I was in the Spirit, and behold, a Throne was ≈øet in Heaven; and one ≈øat on the Throne, &c. And round about the Throne were four and twenty Elders ≈øitting, &c. and out of the Throne proceeded Lightnings, and Thundrings, and Voices; And there were ≈øeven Lamps of Fire burning before the Throne, &c. And in the mid≈øt of the Throne, and round about the Throne were four Bea≈øts, &c.
who re≈øt not day and night, ≈øaying, Holy, Holy Holy, &c. And when tho≈øe Bea≈øts magnify him that ≈øate on the Throne, the four and twenty Elders with profound humility give God the Glory of the Works of his Creation. Then in the fifth Chapter he proceeds to tell us how that the Sitter on the Throne had a Book in his righthand, written within, and on the back-≈øide, ≈øealed with ≈øeven Seals. Whereupon a ≈øtrong Angel is ≈øeen proclaiming with a loud Voice, Who is worthy to open the Book? &c. ver≈ø. 1, 2. None in the whole World is found worthy, ver≈ø. 3. Wherefore St. John weeps, ver. 4. One of the Elders comforts him, ver. 5. Whereupon St. John e≈øpies in the mid≈øt of the Throne a Lamb ≈øtanding as if it had been ≈ølain, &c. ver. 6. who came and took the Book out of the right-hand of him that ≈øate on the Throne, ver. 7. Upon which the ≈øaid Bea≈øts and Elders fall down before the Lamb, and ≈øing a Song to him, congratulating his taking the Book, and opening the Seals, ver. 8, 9, 10. Then the Prophet hears the Voice of many Angels round about the Throne, and the Bea≈øts, and the Elders applauding the Lamb, ver. 11, 12. And next he hears no le≈øs than every Creature in Heaven, Earth, Sea, and under the Earth, giving Ble≈ø≈øing, Honour, Glory and Power to him that ≈øitteth on the Throne, and to the Lamb. The four Bea≈øts ≈øaying Amen; and the Elders doing mo≈øt profound reverence al≈øo, ver. 12, 13. ‚Äî Then he proceeds in Chap. vi. 1, 2, &c. to tell us what he ≈øaw in the Book when the Lamb had opened it. And I ≈øaw (≈øays St. John) when the Lamb opened one of the Seals, and I heard as it were the noi≈øe of Thunder; one of the four Bea≈øts ≈øaying, Come and ≈øee. And I ≈øaw, and behold a white Hor≈øe, and he that ≈øat on him had a Bow, &c. And in like manner he goes on, de≈øcribing what he ≈øaw at the opening of each Sea. ‚Äî Now the thing which I affirm is this, That whether the things which St. John ≈øaw in the Book, be a Prophecy of future things or not; yet it mu≈øt needs be that the many other things which he ≈øaw and heard before the opening of the Book, are a Prophecy. The rea≈øon is plain; becau≈øe tho≈øe words of the Voice [Chap. 4.1. I will ≈øhew thee things that mu≈øt be hereafter] do mo≈øt plainly and immediately affect the things which he ≈øaw in the fourth and fifth Chapters; but not tho≈øe things which he ≈øaw in the Book, Chap. 6. Nor does this only appear from the order of Narration, but al≈øo from the rea≈øon and nature of the the thing it ≈øelf. For tho≈øe words of the Voice [Come up hither, and I will ≈øhew thee things that mu≈øt be
hereafter] mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily refer to the things which the Voice ≈øhew'd him, viz. tho≈øe things which he ≈øaw by virtue of his being call'd up into Heaven; which things are plainly the Throne, with the Sitter on it, together with the other things afore-≈øpoken of. But as for the things that were contained in the Book, he was not ≈øhew'd them by the Voice, but by the Lamb that opened the Book, and the Bea≈øts that called him to ≈øee them; as appears mo≈øt evidently from Rev. 6.1, 2, &c.

Be≈øides, the Title of [things that mu≈øt be hereafter] is not adequate to the Vi≈øions of the ≈øealed Book; who≈øe Events (even according to Dr. M's own Expo≈øition) begin as ≈øoon as tho≈øe of the Epi≈øtolar Prophecy. As therefore the Title to the Epi≈øtolar Prophecy is [things that are, and things that mu≈øt be hereafter, Rev. 1.19.] becau≈øe, as the Doctor truly affirms, the Epi≈øtles concern the ≈øtate of the Church then pre≈øent, as well as that which was to come; why ≈øhould not the Prophecy of the ≈øealed Book have the ≈øame Title, ≈øince the rea≈øon in all points is the ≈øame? So plain is it every way, that tho≈øe words of the Voice [Come up hither, and I will ≈øhew thee things which mu≈øt be hereafter] re≈øpect not the Vi≈øions of the Book, Chap. 6. but tho≈øe that immediately follow the ≈øaid words in Chap. 4.2, 3, &c. viz. the Vi≈øion of the Throne, and the re≈øt that follow.

If therefore the Vi≈øion of the Throne, with the Sitter on it, the Elders and Bea≈øts prai≈øing him, the Book in the Sitter's Righthand, the ≈øtrong Angels proclaiming, &c. I ≈øay, if the≈øe things be not ≈øome of tho≈øe which the Voice points at, Ver≈ø. 1. telling the Prophet he would ≈øhew him things that mu≈øt come to pa≈øs hereafter, it will be impo≈ø≈øible to prove that any part of the Revelation is a Prophecy. Come up hither (≈øays the Voice) and I will ≈øhew thee things that mu≈øt be hereafter. And immediately (≈øays the Prophet) I was in the Spirit, and ≈øaw ≈øuch and ≈øuch things. And are not they the things then which the Voice ≈øaid he would ≈øhew him? Which things, ≈øince the Voice ≈øays they are future things, or things that mu≈øt be hereafter; it is plain the Vi≈øion of them is a Prophecy.

But notwith≈øtanding this mighty Evidence of Truth, the Reverend Dr. M. is plea≈øed to expre≈øs his Wonder (in his Paralipomena Prophetica, Chap. xxi.) that any Man of Wit, and Parts, and Learning ≈øhould be ≈øo heedle≈øs and gro≈øly mi≈øtaken, as to make it a
Prophecy properly ≈øo called, &c. Whereas he that has but the lea≈øt judgment in the World, mu≈øt needs ≈øee (if he will not wilfully wink) that the Spirit him≈øelf ≈øtiles it a Vi≈øion of things to come: And therefore if the Spirit ≈øpeaks properly, the Vi≈øion is properly a Prophecy. But let us hear what that Learned Per≈øon urges in defence of his own Opinion. Now the ≈øub≈øtance of what he alledges in the ≈øaid Chapter is this: That the Vi≈øion of the fourth and fifth Chapters of the Revelation is no more a Prophecy, than that in Ezekiel the fir≈øt; to which al≈øo it is very like in many re≈øpects: as that of Ezekiel is to the glorious Repre≈øentation of the God of I≈ørael made to Mo≈øes and the Elders in the Mount, Exod. xxiv. wherefore as neither that which Ezekiel, or Mo≈øes ≈øaw, was a Prophecy: So neither is it likely that that which St. John ≈øaw is a Prophecy. It is only, or chiefly intended for an Introductory Vi≈øion to the Prophecy of the ≈øealed Book, which begins Chap. 6.1. (a thing u≈øual with the Prophets, as may be ≈øeen I≈øa. 6.1, 2. &c. Ezek. 1. Daniel. 10.5, &c.) and no more a Prophecy than tho≈øe in I≈øaiah, Ezekiel, or Daniel are, intimating the Divine In≈øpiration of John in writing tho≈øe Prophecies, and ≈øetting forth that in pompous and magnificent Expre≈ø≈øions, which is noted in a more vulgar ≈øtile, Rev. 1.1. viz. That God gave his Son the Revelation. To this I an≈øwer; It is here taken for granted that the Vi≈øion which Mo≈øes and Ezekiel ≈øaw in the places afore-cited, is not a Prophecy; which ought to be clearly proved before any ≈øtre≈øs can be laid upon it. But ≈øuppo≈øe it to be no Prophecy (for I cannot ≈øpare time for cavilling) will it thence follow that the Vi≈øion of Rev. iv. & v. is no Prophecy, only becau≈øe in ≈øome things it agrees with that Vi≈øion of Ezekiel, i. e. it ≈øeems to borrow ≈øome of its Types from thence? Are not all Interpereters generally agreed, that the Types in the Revelation are mo≈øtly borrowed from Stories, Rites, and Con≈øtitutions of the Jewi≈øh Church, and taken out of the Old Te≈øtament, as well the Hi≈øtorical as Prophetical Parts of it, and yet no Man denies it to be a Prophecy? For Example, do not both Mr. Mede, and your ≈øelf al≈øo in ≈øeveral Particulars re≈øemble the Prophecy of the Woman, Rev. xii. 1, &c. to the Hi≈øtory of the Children of I≈ørael in Egypt, and coming out of it, Exod. i. and in the following Chapter? And yet you never doubt of its being a Prophecy ere the more for that.

But further, There is a va≈øt difference between the Vi≈øion of Ezekiel and Mo≈øes, and that of St. John, Rev. iv. & v. in that this latter is entitled by the Spirit him≈øelf, [a Vision] of things that mu≈øt be hereafter. Now if the≈øe, or the like words be not prefix'd to that Vi≈øion of Ezekiel, Mo≈øes, or that of Daniel either aforementioned, how can it be thought good rea≈øoning, to ≈øay, tho≈øe Vi≈øions are no Prophecies, therefore this is none?

I expected the Doctor ≈øhould have clear'd this point, (viz. the Argument hitherto in≈øi≈øted on from tho≈øe obvious words, Come up hither, and I will ≈øhew thee things that mu≈øt be hereafter; which are the mo≈øt appo≈øite in the World to prove the Vi≈øion immediately ≈øub≈øequent, to be a Prophecy) but I find not the lea≈øt notice taken of it.
But becau≈øe the Doctor in≈øi≈øts much upon its being an Introductory Vi≈øion to tho≈øe of the ≈øealed Book; as if it could be no Prophecy, if it were an Introductory Vi≈øion.

I an≈øwer, by granting it to be an Introductory Vi≈øion indeed; but no otherwi≈øe Introductory, than the Prophecy of the Sealed-Book introduces that of the Trumpets, Chap. viii. or than that does the Prophecy of the Opened-Book (as the Doctor loves to call it) Chap. xi. 1, &c. Or than the Vi≈øion of the Vials, Chap. xvi. introduces that of the Bea≈øt, Chap. xvii. As one Hi≈øtory may introduce another; ≈øo one Prophecy may introduce another; What ≈øhould hinder? But now, If by an Introductory Vi≈øion be meant a Preface; there is no other ≈øuch as I ≈øee, than that of Chap. iv. 1. where the Voice calls St. John to him, ≈øaying, Come up hither, and I will ≈øhew thee things that mu≈øt be hereafter. This I ≈øay is all the Preface that I can find; for in the very next Ver≈øe begins an account of the things them≈øelves, which the Voice promis'd to ≈øhew him; viz. a Prophetical Repre≈øentation of a glorious Church, with a particular De≈øcription (in the likene≈øs of an Hi≈øtory) of the Beginning, Progre≈øs, and Accompli≈øhment of the Opening of a certain Book, who≈øe Contents are particularly de≈øcribed, Chap. vi. and tho≈øe that follow. So that here is Prophetia in Propheti√¢, i. e. the Prophecy of the Book it ≈øelf, contained in the Prophetical Relation of the opening of it. As if it had been ≈øaid thus: Hereafter ≈øhall ari≈øe a Church like that de≈øcribed Rev. iv. wherein a certain Book ≈øhall be open'd by the Lamb, in ≈øuch manner and circum≈øtances as are de≈øcribed, Chap. v. containing ≈øuch and ≈øuch things as are ≈øaid to
have been ≈øeen in it in the ≈øixth and following Chapters. Now in ≈øuch manner of ≈øpeech as this, who does not ≈øee that the De≈øcription of the Church, and the manner of opening the Book is introductory of the things contained in the Book; and yet is as properly a Prophecy, as that contained in the Book is? To which Prophetical Hi≈øtory of the opening of this Book, tho≈øe words, [Come up hither, and I will ≈øhew thee things that mu≈øt be hereafter is the only Preface. div.head: II. That by opening the ≈øealed Book, Rev. v. is meant Explaining it. And that by the Throne there, is meant a Throne of God on Earth, and not in the highe≈øt Heaven.
div.p: HAving prov'd in the former Sheet, That the Vi≈øion of the fourth and fifth Chapters of the Revelation, is properly a Prophecy of things that were to come to pa≈øs after the exhibiting of it to St. John (notwith≈øtanding what has been alledg'd to the contrary by the Learned Dr. H. M.) I proceed now to ≈øhew, concerning the other Points in di≈øpute between us,
Fir≈øt, That by that Phra≈øe of opening the ≈øealed Book, ≈øo often us'd Rev. v. is meant or prefigur'd the explaining of it.
Secondly, That by the Throne, Rev. iv. 2, &c. is prefigur'd ≈øome Throne of God on Earth, and not his Throne in the highe≈øt Heaven.

Fir≈øt, That by opening the Sealed Book is meant, or prefigur'd the explaining of it. For the truth of this Propo≈øition, I appealed to the con≈øtant and unque≈øtionable u≈øe of that Phra≈øe of opening a Sealed Book, where-ever it occurs throughout the Scripture. As Dan. ix. 24. Seal up the Vi≈øion (viz. that it be not opened) and xii. 4. Seal the Book even to the time of the end. Al≈øo by the ≈øealed Book, I≈øa. xxix. 11. is meant a Book which no Man could open, or under≈øtand. Al≈øo that opening of Prophecies ≈øignifies explaining them, appears from Luke xxiv. 32. where Chri≈øt is ≈øaid to have opened the Scriptures; and Acts xvii. 3. St. Paul is ≈øaid to have opened and alledg'd (viz. out of the Prophecies of the Scripture) that Chri≈øt mu≈øt needs have ≈øuffer'd. Whence the Argument is plain, That if by Sealing a Prophecy be con≈øtantly meant in Scripture concealing the Sen≈øe of it, ≈øo that altho it be written, and in every Man's Hand, yet none knows what it means; and if on the other ≈øide, by opening a Prophecy con≈øider'd as ≈øealed or my≈øterious, be con≈øtantly meant explaining it; it is all the rea≈øon in the World, that it ≈øhould be ≈øo expounded
in the place we are upon, as it is in all other places.

To this the Doctor an≈øwers in the xxxiii Chap. of his Par. Prophetica, by di≈øtingui≈øhing between opening a Book, and opening a Text. To open a Book, is to uncla≈øp it; to open the Text, is to explain it. And thus it is one thing to open a ≈øealed Book where the Prophecy is, and another to open a ≈øealed Prophecy; which is evident from Luke iv. 17. where „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , which ≈øometimes ≈øignifies to explain, ≈øignifies only to open a Book of Prophecies, or to expo≈øe the Writing to view; which, ≈øays the Doctor, is the ca≈øe here of the ≈øeven-≈øealed Book, as appears from Rev. vi. where the opening of the Seals is exemplified, and the meaning ≈øhew'd to be only the exhibiting to John ≈øo many particular Vi≈øions, but not the explaining of tho≈øe Vi≈øions.

Reply 1. The Lamb is ≈øaid Rev. vi. not barely to have opened the Book, but to have opened the Seals of it. Now the Seals of a Book are always upon the Text; for we no where read of a Book ≈øealed any otherwi≈øe than in re≈øpect to the my≈øteriou≈øne≈øs of it. The Seals of a Book are not ≈øuch as may be broken with the Finger, or cut off with a Knife, or mall'd with an Hammer (if the ≈øeven Epi≈øtles indeed had been ≈øaid to have been ≈øealed, we might have had more rea≈øon to have fancied them ≈øuch) but which yield only to the judgment and under≈øtanding of the pious Reader, through the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Spirit of God. And this the Doctor grants, while he ≈øhews him≈øelf very willing, but as little able, to produce one in≈øtance to the contrary. But now if the Seals be always upon the Text, then the Lamb's opening of the Seals in the Vi≈øion, mu≈øt needs figure the opening of the Text, which the Doctor grants to be explaining the ≈øen≈øe of it. And (≈øince I have before proved the Vi≈øion to be a Prophecy) it appears from hence that it is a Prophecy concerning the explaining of the ≈øealed Book; in which the Lamb opening the Seals to St. John, and ≈øhewing him the in≈øide Writing, is a Type of Chri≈øt, or of his Church, that ≈øhould afterwards explain the meaning of it to the Faithful. 2. The Doctor in his Apoc. Apocalyp≈øeos on Rev. v. 1. grants the Seals of the Book to ≈øignify its Arcana; and whereas the Book is ≈øaid to have been written within and on the back-≈øide, the Doctor there expounds the in≈øide Writing to be the inward Sen≈øe of the Book, in oppo≈øition to the literal ≈øen≈øe, which is the back-≈øide writing. Whence it mu≈øt undeniably follow, That to open the Seals of the Book, ≈øo that the in≈øide-writing may be ≈øeen, is to ≈øhew the inward ≈øen≈øe of it; or, which is all one, to explain it.

Wherefore as to what the Doctor ≈øays of the Lamb's opening the Seals Rev. vi. that it is only the exhibiting certain Vi≈øions to St. John, but not explaining them (from whence he peremptorily concludes, that whatever in other places may be meant by opening the Seals of a Book, it cannot be under≈øtood here of explaining it); I an≈øwer, The Doctor to maintain a literal ≈øen≈øe of this Phra≈øe of opening a ≈øealed Book (the ≈øen≈øe which he is ≈øo zealous again≈øt in other ca≈øes) is pleas'd to make him≈øelf extremely ignorant in a point of ordinary cognizance. For why, I be≈øeech you, Sir, may not Chri≈øt's explaining the inward ≈øen≈øe of this Book at ≈øome time or other to his Servants, be fore-≈øignified by the Lamb's opening the Seals of it in the Vi≈øion and ≈øhewing the in≈øide-writing of it to St. John? The Doctor grants the Lamb to repre≈øent Chri≈øt; St. John to repre≈øent the People of God (upon Rev. v. 4.) he grants the in≈øide-writing of the Book to ≈øignify the inward ≈øen≈øe of it (in the place a little afore quoted.) What is it then that he denies? Why, tho he grants all this ≈øingly, yet he denies, when put together, that the Lamb's opening the Seals and ≈øhewing the in≈øide-writing to St. John, ≈øignifies Chri≈øt's explaining at ≈øome time or other to his People the inward Sen≈øe of the Book. Which, how unrea≈øonable a thing it is, I leave to the judgment of any impartial Reader.

It is therefore to me one of the greate≈øt Wonders in the World, that the Doctor who cries up the Apocalyps for a Book ≈øo throughly ≈øymbolical, that he will by no means allow Hail-≈øtones or Earthquakes to be interpreted literally (See Par, Proph. Chap. xlviii. p. 444.) ≈øhould be here ≈øo ≈øtiff for the literal ≈øen≈øe of opening the Seals of a Prophetick Book, which (as God would have it) has no literal ≈øen≈øe at all. But certainly one would be ≈øurpriz'd, who has heard to what a degree the Doctor both derides and pities R.H. of Salisbury (Epilogue to Apoc. Apocalyp≈øeos, p. 297.) for doting on the literal ≈øen≈øe of the Apocalyp≈øe, to ≈øind him caught in the ≈øame ≈ønare him≈øelf, and become as zealous an R. H‚Äîian as the Gentleman he oppos'd, even in a Type or Symbol which is never known to have been us'd in ≈øuch a ≈øen≈øe. For a further Confirmation of the Sen≈øe of which Phra≈øe, I will in≈øtance but in one plain ca≈øe, which we have Dan. xii. 4. where the Prophet is commanded to ≈øeal the Book even to the time of the end. For if opening the Seals of a Book be no more than expo≈øing, the bare words (without ≈øen≈øe) to view; how can the Book of Daniel be ≈øaid to have been ≈øealed to the time of the end, when the words of it have been vi≈øible from
the time of his receiving them? If you ≈øay, That opening the Seals of a Book may ≈øignify only expo≈øing the bare words tho not in that place of Daniel: I de≈øire but what is very fair, That you would ≈øhew me then ≈øome other place, where the Phra≈øe ≈øignifies what you contend; or el≈øe confe≈øs that you have err'd about it.

But if it could be ≈øhew'd (which I believe can never be) that opening the Seals of a Book is ≈øomewhere found to have a literal ≈øen≈øe; yet ≈øuch a ≈øen≈øe not only would be di≈ø≈øonant from the ≈øtile and genius of the Apocalyp≈øe, but in the Vi≈øion we are now upon, impo≈ø≈øible to be true. For in the literal ≈øen≈øe the Seals were open'd by the Lamb in the pre≈øence of St. John 1600 Years ago, at the time of his ≈øeeing this Vi≈øion; whereas I have before manife≈øtly proved this Vi≈øion to be a Prophecy of things that were to come to pa≈øs after. From whence it follows that the Repre≈øentations made to St. John in it, (whereof that of opening the ≈øealed Book is the mo≈øt in≈øi≈øted on of any) are meerly ≈øymbolical, and to be con≈øider'd only as Images of tho≈øe future things.

Moreover there are two other things which make the literal ≈øen≈øe of the Seals open'd in St. John's time impo≈ø≈øible. One is, That no ≈øuch loud Proclamation was ever heard before that opening, as is expre≈øly ≈øaid to have been made before the true opening of them, Rev. v. 2. I ≈øaw (≈øays the Prophet) a ≈øtrong Angel proclaiming with a loud voice; Who is worthy to open the Book, and to loo≈øe the Seals of it? And this Proclamation is repre≈øented as made in the hearing of all the World, as plainly appears from the Return given in upon it in the next Ver≈øe, viz. That no Man in Heaven, in Earth, or under the Earth, was able to open the Book, &c. Whence we may certainly conclude, that if no Man living in St. John's time did ever hear any ≈øuch Proclamation made, then was not that which is meant by opening of the Seals, tran≈øacted in St. John's time. For it ≈øeems very ab≈øurd to infer that no Man was able to open the Book, becau≈øe upon loud (or publick) Proclamation made, no Man appear'd to do it, if no Man then in being ever heard the Proclamation.

To this Dr. M. an≈øwers, That the Proclamation was never made but only in Vi≈øion (Par. Proph. Chap. xxxiv. Re≈øp. ad prim.) And he there al≈øo gives this rea≈øon why it was not needful to be fulfill'd, becau≈øe the Vi≈øion is Dramatical, i. e. in the nature of a Stage-play. And he explains his Sentiments of the Vi≈øion yet more clearly Chap. xxi. p. 189. lin. 19. where ≈øpeaking with re≈øpect to the Vi≈øion in Rev. iv, & v. he tells us that it is the priviledg

So that according to this account, the ivth and vth Chapters of the Revelation are a Play or Show exhibited by the Angelical Kingdom; and for that rea≈øon there needs be no completion of them.

To this I reply, 1. That I have prov'd tho≈øe Chapters to be as much a Prophecy, as any part of the Revelation can be prov'd to be, and that from the clear Te≈øtimony of the Spirit him≈øelf, who has prefix'd the Title of Things that mu≈øt be hereafter to them.

2. If Rev. iv, & v. be a Play that was really acted in Heaven; I de≈øire to be inform'd, 1. Who acted the Sitter on the Throne, and the ≈ølain Lamb, which are the chief Parts in it. The Doctor tells us (Par. Proph. Chap. xxxiv. about the beginning) that by the Sitter on the Throne is meant God, and by the ≈ølain Lamb, Chri≈øt Je≈øus. But it were ab≈øurd to ≈øay, either that they act Plays, or that any Creature acts their Parts. Therefore the Vi≈øion is not Dramatical. 2. It is manife≈øt that tho≈øe under the Earth (by whom the Doctor on the place under≈øtands Wizards, &c.) have a part in this Play too, as may be ≈øeen Rev. v. 3, 13. But none of the Angels in Heaven could have ≈øuch a part put upon them, therefore the Vi≈øion is not a Play acted by Angels, but like other Vi≈øions prefigurative of things to come.

But now as to the rea≈øon why, there needs be no completion of this Vi≈øion, viz. becau≈øe it is Dramatical; this is ≈øo far from being a rea≈øon of it, that (if it were true) it would be a good rea≈øon for the quite contrary. For, 1. How can this be a Prophetical Show or Play (as the Doctor calls it) if it be not to be fulfill'd in ≈øome real thing to come? 2. It is the nature of all Plays to repre≈øent real things; ≈øo far is it from all rea≈øon to imagine a Play acted by Angels to be only a Fiction, as the Proclamation we ≈øpeak of mu≈øt needs be, if it were never made, nor to be made, but only in the Vi≈øion. 3. If the Vi≈øion of the Angel proclaiming, needs not to be punctually fulfill'd, as being a part of a Dramatical Vi≈øion, ≈øince it is certain and confe≈øt by the Doctor him≈øelf that the Vi≈øion of the opening the Seals (whereof that of the Angel proclaiming, is part) reaches to the end of Rev. xi. that they were exhibited only in a Play or Show, and need no more to be fulfill'd than the Vi≈øion of the ≈øtrong Angel we are ≈øpeaking of.

The other thing which makes the literal ≈øen≈øe of opening the Book in St. John's time impo≈ø≈øible to be the ultimate ≈øen≈øe of that Phra≈øe, is that which is ≈øaid Rev. v. 13. where St. John ≈øays he heard every Creature in Heaven, in Earth, in the Sea, and under the Earth, ≈øaying, Ble≈ø≈øing, and Glory, and Honour, and Power be unto him that ≈øitteth upon the Throne, and to the Lamb for ever and ever. In which Hymn ≈øince every Creature was to be concern'd; if it had been ≈øaid in St. John's time, we ≈øhould certainly have had ≈øome foot≈øteps of it in Hi≈øtory. But there is no ≈øuch Pa≈ø≈øage any where to be found, and yet it was to be before the Lamb's opening of the Seals, as plainly appears from the uninterrupted order of Relation, Rev. v. 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, &c. Therefore the true opening of the Seals was not in St. John's time.

To this the Doctor an≈øwers as ≈øtrangely as to the former (Par. Proph. Chap. xxxiv. Re≈øp. ad 10.) not re≈øolving whether it was to have any Completion, or not, as being Dramatical too; but if it ought to be fulfill'd at all, he ≈øays it is not to be till the Millennium, as neither that before it at ver. 9, 10. where the Bea≈øts and Elders ≈øay, they ≈øhall reign upon the Earth.

Reply 1. The Text it ≈øelf ≈øays, That that Hymn of the Bea≈øts and Elders was ≈øung upon the Lamb's taking of the Book (which Dr. M. makes to be in St. John's time) Rev. v. 8. And when the Lamb had taken the Book, they ≈øung, &c. according to which account it ≈øhould have been pa≈øt the≈øe 1600 Years. Likewi≈øe the Hymn ≈øounded forth by every Creature is put before the Lamb's opening any one of the Seals, as is evident to any one that reads. And is it not very ≈øtrange that in the ≈øame uninterrupted Series of Relation, the Lamb's taking the Book Rev. v. 7. ≈øhould have been done 1600 Years ago, but that the Song ≈øaid in the next Ver≈øe to have been ≈øung thereupon, ≈øhould not be fulfill'd till the Millennium, as neither the Gratulation of the Angels, ver. 11, 12. nor the Hymn ≈øaid by every Creature, ver. 13, 14. And that in the very next Ver≈øe, viz. Chap. vi. 1. there ≈øhould be a regre≈ø≈øion to things pa≈øt 1600 Years ago, as the opening of the Book is ≈øaid by Dr. M. to be? 2. Whereas the Doctor makes it an Argument, that the Song of the Bea≈øts and Elders, Chap. v. 8, 9, 10. ≈øhall not be fulfill'd till the Millennium, becau≈øe they ≈øay, they ≈øhall reign upon the Earth; it is plain from tho≈øe words, ≈øhall reign, that their Reign
was not then begun; and con≈øequently, that the Hymn was to be ≈øung before the Millennium. 3. The ‚Ä¢ octor him≈øelf on Rev. xi. 16. makes the≈øe Elders to be our noble Reformers, who are already dead and gone. Al≈øo upon Rov. xv. 7, &c. he expounds the ≈øeven Angels (to whom one of the „Äà‚óä„Äâ Bea≈øts is ≈øaid there to give ≈øeven Vials) to be half path „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Wherefore the Bea≈øt that gave them their Vials mu≈øt „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ≈øomething before the Millennium, which is not yet come. 4. ‚Ä¢ ow arbitrary is it, to make in the ≈øame Vi≈øion, the Bea≈øts and Elders, Chap. v. 8. to ≈øigure ≈øomething to come; but the ≈øtrong Angel proclaiming, ver. 2. to figure nothing at all, (altho in all the Epi≈øtles, and in many other places, the Angels of the Churches are by the current of Interpreters expounded Men; and ought to be ≈øo in all places of the Prophecy, for ought I ≈øee yet to the contrary) nor the opening of the Seals to ≈øigure any thing here, tho it be never us'd but figuratively in any other place? As to the other Point, viz. That by the Throne in the Vi≈øion I am upon, is meant a Throne of God upon Earth; becau≈øe I cannot bring the proof of it within the compa≈øs of this Sheet of Paper, I re≈øerve it to another, if God permit. Tho it may ≈øeem to be prov'd already, in that, 1. The Throne is plainly one of tho≈øe things which the Spirit expre≈øly calls things future, Rev. iv. 1, 2, &c. If by opening the Seals, be meant explaining the Book to the People of God (as I have prov'd it is) then it mu≈øt needs follow, that the Lamb with ≈øeven Horns and ≈øeven Eyes, that opens the Book, is not Chri≈øt him≈øelf in Per≈øon, but the Church of Chri≈øt (as the Lamb, Rev. xvii. 14. is expounded, Rev. xiii. 7. and even by rea≈øon it ≈øelf.) div.head: III. More Arguments to ≈øhew, That by the Throne, Rev. iv. & v. is meant a Throne of God on Earth, and not in the highe≈øt Heaven. With An≈øwers to Objections.
div.p: TO the two Arguments made u≈øe of in the former Sheet, to prove that by the Throne, Rev. iv, & v. is meant ≈øome Throne of God on Earth, and not in the highe≈øt Heaven; I now add,
